CameraTrapMetadataStandard.ProjectName: White Mountains Horse-Cattle-Elk Forage Determination Study
CameraTrapMetadataStandard.ProjectObjectives: Determine how much forage (either as a percentage of total forage or absolute units) horses, cattle, and elk each respectively utilize in two sensitive riparian areas on the Springerville and Alpine Distrcits of the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forests, in the White Mountains of Arizona.
CameraTrapMetadataStandard.ProjectDesign: Camera traps were placed in two targeted riparain areas, Boggy and Wildcat Creeks. These riparian areas were selected because they are designated as crtical habitat for the New Mexico Meadow Jumping Mouse. In each riparian area, there are two sites, one site is unfenced and recieves grazing by horses, cattle, and elk. The second site in each riparian area is fenced off by 4-strand barbed wire about 1.2m (4ft) high. A camera trap set to take 1 photo every minute 24hrs per day is set at each site. Additionally, at the unfenced site in each riparian area, we set a motion camera trap and a camera trap set to take 1 photo every 5 minutes.
CameraTrapMetadataStandard.ProjectDataAccessandUseConstraints: Data is under an embargo until January 1, 2025 or until publicly released as part of publication in an academic journal by the owners of the data.
